abstract.title: EPUB Publications 3.0
abstract.para: EPUB is an interchange and delivery format for digital publications based on XML and Web Standards. EPUB3, the third major revision of EPUB, is defined by a set of specification documents including this document, which defines publication-level semantics and conformance requirements for EPUB3.

annotation.dc:creator: mgylling
annotation.dc:title: EPUB3 Package Metadata Vocabulary
annotation.dc:description: This vocabulary, a part of EPUB 3.0, defines a set of metadata properties for use in Package Documents.

section.title: Purpose and Scope
section.para: This document, EPUB Publications 3.0, defines publication-level semantics and conformance requirements for EPUB3, the third major revision of EPUB, an interchange and delivery format based on XML and Web Standards.

This document is meant to be read and understood in concert with the other documents that make up EPUB3. The EPUB3 Overview , which provides an informative overview of EPUB and a roadmap to the rest of the EPUB3 documents, should be read first.

section.title: Relationship to Other Specifications
section.para: This specification depends on other sibling specifications, as described in . Sibling specifications include EPUB Content Documents 3.0 , Open Container Format 3.0 , and EPUB Media Overlays 3.0 .

This specification defines constructs based on XML , and by default all terminology used in this specification has the same meaning as its use in . This specification also relies on XML Namespaces , and in this specification the term "XML namespace" (or just "namespace") has the meaning defined in that specification.
EPUB Publications 3.0 is a revision to, and supersedes, Open Package Format 2.0.1 .

chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: EPUB is an interchange and delivery format for digital publications, based on XML and Web Standards. An EPUB Publication can be thought of as a a reliable packaging of Web content that represents a digital book, magazine, or other type of publication, with a declarative means to navigate through the content, and the ability to be distributed reliably for online and offline consumption.

This specification defines the semantics and conformance requirements for EPUB at the publication level. It defines the formats of the Package and NCX documents, as well as rules for how these documents and other Publication resources are associated to create a conforming EPUB Publication. This specification also defines rules for how EPUB Publications are processed by conforming Reading Systems.

chapter.title: EPUB Publications
chapter.para: This section describes the high-level content and Reading System conformance requirements for EPUB Publications. The sections following this one describe more specifically the requirements for Package Documents, NCX Documents, and Core Media Types.

section.title: Publication Content Conformance
section.para: A EPUB Publication minimally consists of the following Publication Resources:

listitem.para: Exactly one Package Document, conformant to the requirements defined in
Exactly one NCX Document, conformant to the requirements defined in
One or more EPUB Content Documents, conformant to the requirements defined for EPUB Content Documents in
Zero or more EPUB Style Sheets, conformant to the content conformance requirements defined for EPUB Style Sheets in
Zero or more Media Overlay Documents, conformant to the content conformance requirements defined in

Zero or more additional resources, with content conformance requirements inferred from their media type unless explicitly specified differently by this specification or one of its sibling specifications.

section.para: An EPUB Publication is instantiated as an EPUB File, i.e. in a ZIP container conformant with the requirements in .

section.para: A conforming Reading System is not necessarily a single dedicated program or device, but may exist as a distributed system. A wide variety of legitimate presentations of Publications by Reading Systems are contemplated by the EPUB3 specification suite.

In addition to conforming with the requirements specific to this specification, an EPUB Reading System must necessarily also be a conforming User Agent according to and a conforming OCF Processor according to . An EPUB Reading System must also, if it supports Media Overlays, be a confoming Media Overlay Processor according to .

EPUB Reading Systems conformant with this Publications 3.0 specification should also be conformant processors of EPUB version 2 publications, as defined by , , and , and must at a minimum attempt to process any publication whose Package Document designates a version other than "3.0" or which omits the version attribute, as if such publication had designated a version "3.0"; provided, however, that Reading Systems must in this situation ignore the presence of removed constructs including ops:switch in Content Documents and @fallback-style in manifest items.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: The fundamental publication-level construct of an EPUB Publication is the . The Package Document provides central information about the publication as a whole, and about the individual resources that comprise the publication:

listitem.para: Publication metadata - mechanisms for including and/or referencing metadata applicable to the entire Publication and particular resources within it.
A Publication manifest, which identifies (via URI) and describes (via MIME type) the set of resources that collectively comprise the Publication.

A spine - an ordered sequence of id references to top-level resources in the manifest, from which all other resources in the set can be reached or utilized. The spine defines the default "reading order" of the publication.
Navigation - a publication-wide declarative navigation layer.
Fallback chains - an optional means for publications to define an ordered list of items that can be considered informational equivalents, that a Reading System can choose between in rendering content
Bindings - an optional means of associating script-based implementations with custom media types.

section.title: Metadata extensibility
section.para: This specification subsets the RDFa 1.1 profile and prefix definition mechanisms to simplify the inclusion and extension of metadata vocabularies for defining publications. These new features allow core metadata properties to be added unprefixed and additionally work to standardize the inclusion of metadata across the publishing spectrum by predefining prefixes for the most commonly-used vocabularies.

All publications must reference the metadata profile on the root package element using the profile attribute. Unlike its RDFa equivalent, the profile attribute must only contain the single canonical URI of the EPUB default profile.

informalexample.para: The following example shows how the metadata profile is defined.

section.para: The addition of the metadata profile allows all properties from the EPUB3 Package Metadata Vocabulary to be referenced without using prefixes. The profile also defines a set of prefixes for use adding other vocabulary properties to EPUB Publications (refer to the profile for more information).

If the RDFa profile does not define a prefix for a needed vocabulary, it does not imply that the vocabulary cannot be included for use. The prefix attribute can also be attached to the package element to define additional prefixes. New prefixes are defined by including whitespace-separated prefix/URI pairings.

section.para: It is not permitted to use the prefix attribute to redeclare a prefix that has already been defined in the metadata profile. The method of defining namespace prefixes must similary not be used to define vocabulary prefixes.

section.title: Overview
section.para: The metadata element encapsulates information about the publication as a whole, including metadata that applies to the publication package and to the abstract content contained within the package. Metadata is expressed through a combination of three required Dublin Core Metadata Element Set properties — title, identifier and language — coupled with optional properties from DCMI Metadata Terms . These metadata terms can be further enhanced and extended by a set of optional properties also defined in this specification.

Properties from other RDF vocabularies may be added to the metadata section to enhance package and content metadata and to supplement required and optional properties, but Reading System support for them should not be assumed.

section.title: Dublin Core Metadata Vocabulary Transition
section.para: This specification represents the beginning of a shift from traditional XML-based grammars to RDFa vocabularies for expressing metadata. Unlike XML grammars, which intrude into host grammars and require specific accommodations to work, RDFa is a more natural and fluid means of expressing metadata, working within existing attributes to a greater degree of semantic richness than would otherwise be possible.

The addition of RDFa support for the expression of metadata now allows properties from a wide variety of vocabularies to be easily incorporated for expressing and refining information about the package and its contents. RDFa properties also do not require the importing of new grammars, but allow properties to be expressed via meta elements. (For more information, refer to the .)

Although the requirement to include the core title, identifier and language elements has not changed with this release, their inclusion is focused on maintaining backwards compatibility during this period of transition, and their deprecation is expected in a future version. Content authors are instead encouraged to begin using the new properties from the Dublin Core Metadata Terms vocabulary, including the properties that supersede the required DCMES elements (see add link to override).

section.title: The DCMES identifier Element
section.para: Every metadata section must include at least one identifier element containing an unambiguous identifier for the package. Multiple identifier elements are permitted, but only one can be marked as the primary identifier for the package via the package element's unique-identifier attribute.

section.para: The meta element provides a generic means of expressing metadata, both to express primary metadata about the package or content or to refine that metadata. All meta elements must attach the RDFa property attribute that contains a CURIE that resolves to a property from an RDF vocabulary (it is not required that Reading System be able to resolve the CURIES).
If a meta element only includes a property attribute, the metadata is assumed to apply to the package or content as a whole.

With the exception of package properties, all metadata properties noted in the following sections can be used to annotate other metadata properties in the package.

section.title: Overview
section.para: The manifest element provides an exhaustive list of all s that constitute the Publication via its collection of child item elements.

All s must be referenced in the manifest regardless of their physical location (i.e., regardless of whether they are available in the or remotely). Refer to for media type specific requirements regarding resource locations.

This specification and its sibling specifications may explicitly define certain resource types to be external, thereby declaring that the resource is not a Publication Resource. Examples of such external resources include resources referenced from the Package Document metadata element.
The manifest is not self-referencing: it must not include item elements referring to the resource(s) that make up the Package Document itself.
The order of item elements in the manifest is not significant. The presentation sequence of Content Documents is provided in spine.

section.title: Overview
section.para: Each item element in the manifest identifies a resource belonging to the EPUB Package by the URI provided in its href attribute. The URI provided may be absolute or relative to the container. In the case of relative URIs, Reading Systems will use the URI of the Package Document in order to resolve these to absolute URIs. The resulting absolute URI must be unique within the manifest scope.
The resource identified by an item must conform to the applicable specification(s) as inferred from the MIME Type provided in the item element media-type attribute.

section.title: Item Fallbacks
section.para: Unless one of the exceptions listed in apply, each item in the manifest whose value is not one of the EPUB3 Core Media Types must use the attribute to specify a fallback chain that includes at least one whose is an EPUB3 Core Media Type.

The fallback attribute IDREF value must resolve to another item in the manifest. The ordered list of all ID references that can be reached starting from a given item's fallback attribute is considered to be the "fallback chain" for that item. There must not be any circular- or self references in fallback chains.

The general rule for processing manifest-level fallbacks is that a Reading System that does not support the Media Type of a given item must traverse the fallback chain until it encounters a supported Media Type. The resource identified by the fallback item is then used in place of the unsupported item. It is legal to have a fallback attribute on an item of a Core Media Type and a Reading System may choose to "fall over" such references in order to find the optimal version of a resource to render in a given context. TODO Fallbacks for NCX, and possibly other core media types, are not legal. Determine which they are and add here.

However, Reading Systems process fallbacks differently depending on the context where a reference to a resources occurs in Content Documents, in conjunction with the intrinstic fallback mechanisms defined in , and . Refer to for a definition of the overall processing flow for handling fallbacks.

section.title: Scripted Content Documents
section.para: In EPUB Publications, Content Documents must not contain any script elements unless the manifest item corresponding to that Content Document contains the property value scripted (thus indicating a Scripted Content Document).Since scripted content may be processed differently, with features such as pagination potentially disabled, content items that set the property value of "scripted" should not be spine items unless absolutely required by a publication (i.e. scripted content should if possible be nested, contained within top-level content via "object" or "iframe").

Reading Systems may render Scripted Content Documents as an interactive, scripted HTML User Agent according to rather than according to the simplified processing model defined for EPUB User Agents in , i.e. with scripting enabled. Reading Systems should not enable scripting for any resources other than Scripted Content Documents.

Reading Systems may implement support for Scripted Content Documents in a manner that disables other EPUB capabilities and/or provides a different rendering such as, for example, disabling pagination.

section.title: The spine element
section.para: The spine element defines the default reading order of the Publication content.

listitem.para: Third child of , following .
An IDREF to the manifest that represents the NCX

section.para: The spine elements children is a list of s. The order in which the itemref elements appear defines the default reading order of the Publication.

section.title: The itemref element

listitem.para: As a child of . Repeatable.
Identifies via an IDREF a manifest element.
Specifies whether the referenced content is primary. Value must be yes or no.
Indicates the directional placement of a single spine item. Value must be left or right.

section.para: Each itemref element must (via the attribute) reference an item in the manifest. Consequently, the spine represents an ordered list of a subset of the items in the manifest, with content items not being referenced from the spine being ancillary to those that do appear there.

Each item referenced via itemref must be an . Note that in general such references should resolve to XHTML Content Documents rather than SVG Content Documents, unless a) such use is within a Publication that is packaged together with, and as an alternative non-default representation of, another Publication that represents effectively the same content utilizing XHTML Content Documents or b) the nature of the content being represented via SVG is inherently unsuitable to representation in XHTML.

The itemref element's linear attribute indicates whether a spine item is considered primary (linear='yes') or auxiliary (linear='no').The default value of linear is yes. This may be used to enable Reading Systems to distinguish presentation of "body" content from ancillary content which might be, for example, presented in a popup window, or omitted from an aural rendition.

Reading Systems must provide a means to render a Publication in the order defined by the spine. Reading Systems must as part of this means a) recognize the first primary (linear='yes') item in spine to be the beginning of the main reading order of the publication, and b) render successive primary items in the order given in spine.

The vocabulary defined for the property attribute of the itemref element includes the values left and right which specify the desired placement of a single-page rendering of that item. This is intended to facilitate representation of two-page "spreads". section.para: The package element may contain at most one bindings element, which contains one or more mediaType elements, each of which associates a custom media type with a "handler" that provides a default script-based implementation for items of that media type when they are referenced from object elements in XHTML Content Documents.

Each mediaType element must uniquely designate, via its required media-type attribute, a unique content type, which must not be a Core Media Type, and must reference, via its required handler attribute, the id in the manifest of the default implementation for this media type, which must be an XHTML Content Document.

Reading Systems that support scripting must utilize the bindings element, if present in a Publication, to handle object element references whose MIME media type is not natively supported by the Reading System. The processing model is to instantiate for such references the designated XHTML Content Document handler (which would typically include scripting) as if it had been referenced from the object element's data attribute, but with URL parameters (which go after '?' in a URL) of
src - URI to the resource (value of the data attribute in the object element)
type - resource media type (value of the type attribute in the object element)

section.title: Fallback Requirements and Processing Flow
section.para: This section defines in detail the requirements for including fallback content in a , and the process by which Reading Systems must process fallback information. The rules for fallback processing depend on both the type of item, and how is referenced by a Content Document or other resource.
Unless specified otherwise in the sections below, fallbacks must be provided for any that is not a Core Media Type using the manifest fallback mechanism.

section.title: Audio and Video
section.para: A Reading System that supports video playback must support video files that utilize the MPEG-4 container with H.264/MPEG-4 AVC baseline profile format (H.264) video codec and MPEG-4 Advanced Audio Coding - Low Complexity (AAC-LC) audio codec, and this format is a Core Media Type.

A Reading System that supports audio playback must support MPEG-1 Layer 3 (MP3) audio, and this format is a Core Media Type. Any Reading System that supports video playback must also support standalone AAC-LC audio playback, but AAC-LC is NOT a Core Media Type.

section.title: XHTML Content Documents
section.para: For every referenced from an that is not a Core Media Type, suitable fallback(s) to a resource that is a Core Media Type must be provided as detailed below:

listitem.para: For resources referenced via the object element, legitimate fallback(s) must be provided via that element’s intrinsic replacement capabilities.

Reading Systems must ignore manifest-level fallbacks in resolving such references. (Note that the bindings element could be considered to enable a type of fallback, but not in the sense meant here of ensuring that content can be rendered on all Reading Systems, whether or not they support scripting).
For resources referenced via img elements, the text value of the alt attribute provides a legitimate fallback and should be included. Additional manifest-level fallbacks may be provided.
Reading Systems should process manifest-level fallbacks in resolving such references.
For all other resource referencing situations in XHTML content documents, a legitimate fallback must be provided via the manifest fallback mechanism.
Reading Systems must process manifest-level fallbacks in resolving such resource references.

note.para: Only XHTML Content Documents must be referenced via iframe elements; fallback processing is inapplicable.

section.title: Embedded Fonts
section.para: For fonts embedded in Content Documents or EPUB Style Sheets using the @font-face mechanism, the rules of CSS must be used to provide an appropriate fallback in case a non-standard or font format is embedded (such fallback may be an OpenType or WOFF embedded font or a reference to a system font).
Reading Systems must ignore manifest-level fallbacks in resolving CSS font references.
